thread.title: City High football ‘feeling good’ about fourth straight win
thread.title_full: City High football ‘feeling good’ about fourth straight win

title: City High football ‘feeling good’ about fourth straight win
text:
City High football ‘feeling good' about fourth straight win City High football ‘feeling good' about fourth straight win HS journalism: Little Hawks hosting Burlington Friday Community Corner by JR Ogden , Iowa City High , Iowa Prep Sports , Prep Football , Sports , Photos The City High football captains take the field before last Friday’s win at Prairie. (Joseph Cress photo/City High) Iowa Football Data Center

Sharing community and high school contributed stories Wednesday October 07, 2015 Bu Jonathan House, City High junior October 7, 2015 | 3:47 pm 
CEDAR RAPIDS — After a scoreless first half, and part of the third quarter, both the City High and Cedar Rapids Prairie offenses came alive. 
City High won its fourth straight game, 28-21, to improve to 4-2 overall, and 2-0 in the district. 
The two teams scored a combined seven touchdowns in the second half. 
Senior Jason Jones started the scoring on a short touchdown catch on third-and-goal from junior Jared Taylor. 
“I don’t know for sure. Things just started happening, I think both teams got a little more confidence in their offense, and confidence says a lot,” City High Coach Dan Sabers said of the offenses in the second half. “In the first half we moved it some, we just weren’t able to finish it.” 
Prairie responded with a quick touchdown, but City High came back just as quick with touchdown run from senior Will Noack. Noack came off the bench and scampered 68 yards down the sideline to the end zone. 
City High responded with another Jason Jones touchdown with 6:16 to play in the fourth quarter. 
“Jason is special and one of his best plays was a block he made on the last touchdown,” Sabier said. “That’s the kind of player Jason Jones is. He doesn’t take a play off and he goes hard every time. We’re very fortunate to have him.” 
The block Jones made came with just over two minutes left to play when City High had the ball with a 21-14 lead. Taylor handed off to junior Bryce Frantz, who found plenty of room to run down the left side of the field. Frantz finished with more than 100 yards rushing. 
Prairie added a late touchdown, but City recovered the onside kick and ran out the clock. 
“Anytime you get a win, we’ve played these guys for years (City High played Prairie often in the Mississippi Valley Conference before the shift to district play was made last year),” Sabers said. “We always know their kids are hard-nosed, tough kids, and that’s what they were tonight. 
“So we feel really good about the win.” 
City High hosts Burlington (1-5) Friday at Bates Field.
